whySimilar.title: Most websites look the same
whySimilar.paragraph1: Their job is not to inform you, they're fine-tuned machines guiding you to enter your credit card.
whySimilar.paragraph2: The urgency and pressure? Not signs of excitement! Just conversion optimization pushing for your credit card details.

specialOffer.title: Special Offer
specialOffer.copy: ðŸš¨ Special Offer Banner - creates urgency, pushes you to act fast! ðŸš¨

dataTrail.title: Data > Oil
dataTrail.note: * Fetching a rough, IP address based location (no GPS)

cookies.title: Cookies - sweet or clingy?
cookies.paragraph1:
Your barista remembers your latte and your name. Sweet!
First-party cookies do that - login, preferences, did you see A or B and that shopping cart you abandoned.
cookies.paragraph2:
Guy in a van? Different vibe.
Third-party cookies follow you everywhere, log everything, report to advertisers. That abandoned cart haunting every page? That's them.
cookies.firstParty: First-party cookies: set by the site you're on â€” logins, carts, "remember me," that sort of useful stuff.
cookies.sessionPersistent: Session vs. persistent: session cookies vanish when you close the tab; persistent cookies stick around for days or months, like glitter after a craft accident.
cookies.retargTitle: Retargeting in 4 steps (aka "why am I seeing those exact shoes?")
cookies.retargStep1: You check out Product X on Site A. A tiny "ad pixel" from AdCo loads.
cookies.retargStep2: AdCo drops a thirdâ€‘party cookie: "User looked at Product X."
cookies.retargStep3: Later on Site B (also running AdCo), your browser presents that cookie to AdCo.
cookies.retargStep4: AdCo recognizes you and serves an ad for Product X everywhere, forever. Or at least until the cookie expires.
cookies.note: Note: Many browsers now block third-party cookies by default. Retargeting still happens via newer tricks (first-party tracking, server-side stitching, hashed emails). The game evolves.

abTesting.title: Choose A or B
abTesting.optionA: A. Opinions are vibes, revenue decides
abTesting.optionB: B. Hunches are cheap, data is truth
abTesting.line4: Split 100,000 visitors - half see A, half see B. Let the wallets vote.
abTesting.line5: That's called A/B testing. Like Darwin for profits.
abTesting.copyA:
Split 100,000 visitors - half see A, half see B. Let the wallets vote.
That's called A/B testing. Like Darwin for profits.
abTesting.copyB: Randomly show half the visitors A others B. Which copy gets more sales remains. Survival of the fittest.

freeMaterials.title: Free* materials
freeMaterials.body: *Price: email and attention. Can't convert you now? We'll try again tomorrow in your inbox.
freeMaterials.body2: Except here. No email. No asterisk. Just scroll for your free materials ;)

tricks.title: Persuasion tricks in plain sight
tricks.body: Your interface isn't neutral. Inline prompts, progress meters, social proof â€” every microcopy push keeps you moving forward.
tricks.body2: Spot scarcity timers, risk-free guarantees, checkout microcopy, unstoppable autoplay. Once you see them, you can't unsee them.

personalNote.title: Personal Note
personalNote.paragraph1: Marketers say I'm doing it wrong, this site breaks all the rules.
personalNote.paragraph2: Good! Those rules hooked me for years - games, videos, social feeds, porn, gambling, doomscrolling news. Ruined my sleep, physical and mental health, relationships.
personalNote.paragraph3: I'm not anti-tech. I'm a techie actually and I'm quite fond of my gadgets! I'm just anti-ad-driven-manipulative-design and against our attention being sold for pennies.
personalNote.paragraph4: You're not broken. Your brain's been hacked. Let's get it back by taming your phone

aboutMe.title: About Me
aboutMe.body: I'm building this approach because personality beats blandness. I believe trust grows when you see I'm not hiding behind cookie-cutter methods. This is who I am.

aboutGadgetTaming.title: About gadgetTaming
aboutGadgetTaming.body: gadgetTaming is about understanding how websites really work, beyond templates, and using that knowledge to stand out. Yes, the end goal is sales, but done in a way that respects human attention.

recap.title: Recap
recap.patterns: Websites reuse proven persuasion patterns because they consistently guide visitors toward action.
recap.intro: You're surfing on {{device}} {{referrer}} Not sure where you are, but I can make a guess* ...
recap.data: Your browser leaks a data trailâ€”browser, device, referrer, even rough locationâ€”before you click anything.
recap.popups: Pop-ups are timed nudges; annoying, yes, but effective when matched to behavior.
recap.trust: Trust is earned with proof: testimonials, track record, and transparent storytelling.
recap.action: All of these tactics converge on one decision: the final call to action.

callToAction.title: "Sooo ... what do you want me to buy?"
callToAction.body:
Every page funnels to one thing: the CTA (Call To Action). Order. Buy. Subscribe. Book. Sign up. Send inquiry.
Just one colorful button with a single goal. (Yeah, I broke that rule too)
callToAction.offer: Good instinct! Always be skeptical! You've now become a level 1 gadgetTamer.
callToAction.notReady:
Not ready yet?
Just scroll down to learn more about me, gadgetTaming and the tricks used against you.

callToActionSecondary.title: Almost level 2 gadgetTamer
callToActionSecondary.body: Any of these will get you there and beyond. This is either the end of the road or the beginning of something new - your choice.

shared.title: Why a Pop-Up?
shared.desc:
Last-ditch guilt trip. Clock runs out or you try to leave.
You hate it. It works anyway.
